summary: Nicholas B. Stevenson was a Sergeant in the USAF whose recollections were relevant to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) investigation into the JFK assassination. He was interviewed by the HSCA regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen, specifically concerning events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland. The NSA reviewed reports of these interviews, ensuring the classification of certain portions, particularly those related to a facility capable of collecting data from the Lisbon-Tangier link. His testimony was considered sensitive enough to warrant classification and careful handling via COMINT channels.
significance: Nicholas B. Stevenson's significance lies in his potential knowledge of events or information relevant to the JFK assassination, specifically related to communications intelligence activities at USA-55 in Scotland. His interview by the HSCA and the subsequent NSA review and classification of related reports suggest that his testimony was considered important to the investigation, particularly concerning possible connections to Cuban involvement or other sensitive intelligence matters.
